text: <@UCSPU2GQL> has joined the channel
<!channel> - hi all - We just put out new releases.  Here are the drp release notes.  <https://github.com/digitalrebar/provision/releases/tag/v3.11.0>

attachments.title: digitalrebar/provision
attachments.text: Digital Rebar Provision is a simple and powerful Golang executable that provides a complete API-driven DHCP/PXE/TFTP provisioning system. - digitalrebar/provision

text: The UX is still propagating through the mess that is Amazon.  That is 24hours out …. or sooner
UX includes ability to save searches and collapse the menus!  For people w/ orgs, we can even add custom menu sections for your favorite screens
i have a param that holds the name of another param - anyone know how I get the value of the second param from just the first? :smile:
i tried like `{{ .Param (.Param "first-param") }}` but it didn’t like that :disappointed:
I’ll check .  it may not be supported.
i’ll give that a shot next :slightly_smiling_face:
<@UBXEU90UQ> you can also then use the DRPCLI to pull the value during run time
knows that not as cool
Haha yeah that's my fallback plan
I upgraded my POC to 3.11.0. It was boring and everything worked as expected.
well - expect one thing.  content pack update coming soon.  :slightly_smiling_face:
in the task-library content pack, the `drpcli-install` task installs two systemd services, _drpcli.service_ and _drpcli-init.service_. What is the latter and when, if ever, is it executed?
The init service is a one-shot-ish.  It marks the machine runnable on reboot.  It only does it once.  Once that is finished, the other service runs the runner.
<!channel> - v1.11.1 for community and contrib content to fix bugs.
<@UCTDAPG0M> has joined the channel
<@UCTE5HVRB> has joined the channel
:wave:
<@UCTE5HVRB> <@UCTDAPG0M> $welcome
Digital Rebar welcome information is here > <http://rebar.digital/community/welcome.html>
Thanks <@U02DGQYK1>! We’re kicking the DR tires as we speak — looking for a suitable replacement for RackHD, which sadly Dell decided to kill (sound familiar?!) :smile:
Time to feed the :bear:!
At a deeply personal level.  :slightly_smiling_face:
There is even more history to that, but beers would be required.
I’m game :beers:
<@UCTE5HVRB> - let us know if you need help.

Well, first off, I don’t see anything in the current provision codebase around CoreOS CL — we are going to try to add it as a custom Boot Environment, but I’m curious if there’s a reason it’s not there already…
We wanted to save something exciting for you...
hey thanks greg
ire
ire can be exciting
<@UCTE5HVRB> - there are some things to think about with the CoreOS model that we didn’t want to fight about.  And then RedHat bought them up and well less general excitement.
ire was mostly a joke.   There are couple of questions you need to answer with CoreOS (or did when I looked at it a year ago).

<@U02DGQYK1> I can understand that. In our case, we have a strong internal project around Ignition-based provisioning, so it probably won’t be too difficult to get something set up that allows us to push an ignition file into our workflow, rather than having dr-provision create the same for us via the templating system you’ve built.
okay - so you have CoreOS knowledge and power.  That is a good first step.  That was one of the questions.
1. netboot vs disk-based
2. fight ignition or embrace ignition
3. where does the initial config.yaml come from?
Any red flags if we just set up a workflow where we set boot params: `coreos.first_boot=` `coreos.config.url` and we’re off to the races?
not sure if that could muck up the way your workflows work having the ignition data be remote
that would be a bootenv with bootparams referencing templates for ignition and config.
sounds straightforward enough
It is, but ….  This is the part where we talk a little philosophy and why CoreOS is an oddball.
With Workflows and stages and tasks and all the parts of DRP, we’ve defined a system of composition.  The composition is build things up from validated aggregate pieces and continue.
It may be worth some investigation into Sledgehammer and the immutable deploys with KRIB as a reference.  It has benefits like CoreOS but provides more control in a Centos base.

CoreOs is counter to that.  It kind says go.  You have to know completely what you want the system to be and what is needs to be laid out at the start.  Now, one is actually a subset of the other.   DRP can handle CoreOS completely as a templated system, but the workflow composition becomes less interesting for it.  Completely doable.
and my typing is horrid today

Thank you both for the guidance there. In this case unfortunately we don’t have a choice about the OS. We’re building out the datacenter implementation of our k8s-based stack. The Azure/AWS implementations are basically done, and we’re wanting as little variance between the clouds as possible (so CoreOS is here to stay — until it changes for all 3 clouds).
And to <@U02DGQYK1>’s last point, that’s totally fine. We re-provision if we want to make changes to a system.
not saying it is a problem.  Just explaining why we haven’t focused on CoreOs.
The final difference is one of general use versus specific use.

You have a specific use.  You have a coreos config file that has all the tweaks for your deployment, networking, app config, logging requirements, ….  With an ignition file that defines disk layouts more.  I couldn’t (with creating yet another DSL) make a composite way to build that file incrementally.

So, the general case of supporting CoreOs is hard.  Take a centos install.  I can install base centos and then add tasks to customize by installing additional packages or running ansible/chef/puppet/scripts to customize.  CoreOS makes that harder.

Yep, I have a deep & painful understanding of that shortcoming of CoreOS :slightly_smiling_face:
We occasionally use Ansible to make small(ish) changes without re-provisioning nodes, and they certainly don’t make that easy.
Of course with all that whining out of the way, the latest DRP has parameters, profiles, and sub-templating, I suspect a pretty rich dynamic CoreOS ignition and config file could be constructed.

While we won’t be pushing for that (because of the overlap with our internal project), It’s good to know you’ve thought through it. Who knows, a year from now CoreOS CL may not even be around anymore.
The biggest challenge is going to be letting DRP know CoreOS is done “installing” and complete.
yeah, “Done” is a bit of a misnomer with our RackHD install: <https://github.com/RackHD/on-taskgraph/blob/master/data/templates/install-coreos.sh#L36>
Once the `coreos-install` is done running, we mark it done :slightly_smiling_face:
That will work.
Force the workflow stage to `complete` or whatever.
The esxi templates do this.
well kickstart template for esxi
Our VMware team will be thrilled to know there’s support. VMware’s auto-deploy is a mess.
There is a “better” way, depending upon what you want to run.
<@UCTDAPG0M> :point_up:
aye, yeah i'm snooping
i mean we've only just installed this, and it's taken a fradtion of a time to get something up and recognized
than with rackhd. i mean i'm excited about this
well - The ESXI deploy raw ESXI.  We are looking / wanting to work with people on how to make that snazzy for VCenter.
yeah, it’s a non-starter for them if the nodes aren’t put into vCenter as part of the provisioning workflow
maybe an area we can contribute to
Yeah, but what does that mean?  Where does the process start?  Is it push or pull?  I don’t have Vcenter licenses to play with it.  We think it could be amazing.
Back to CoreOS install being done.
Our use-case would be push-based. We want a centralized provisioning system that can work with multiple types of distributed systems (vCenter included)
So, we’d say: provision node X, with such config, and put it in vCenter Y
A different tact is to use the template system to “enhance” the starting container config inside of CoreOS on start-up, so that it runs a drpcli runner that completes the process.
That’s a neat idea
I do have a separate question if you don’t mind a topic change…
please - the rest of the channel has nodded off at my ramblings.  :slightly_smiling_face:
We’ll be kicking the tires with DRP using some Open Compute servers starting this week. One of the biggest open questions we have is around hardware config & firmware management.
The servers support RedFish, which makes some of that easier (when implemented).
How complete is the DRP story around flashing firmware, configuring BIOS/RAID, etc?
I saw a bunch of code around Dell, but like RackHD, it seems that’s largely unexplored but that there’s a decent framework in place…?
Time to feed the :bear:!
Yeah - so, the flash, bios, raid pieces are modular.
We support Dell gear really really well.
Time to feed the :bear:!
Supermicro a little.
The rest are TBD as we get access to hardware.
The underlying modules are easy enough to expand and support for, but we need access to hardware for a couple of weeks to make the changes.
<@U02DJQSG8> looked at Redfish and started playing with it some, but that was a while back.  Not sure the state of it.  We wouldn’t be starting cold though.
OK, I’m sure we’ll have more questions as we go along. Thanks much for inviting us into your playground.
<@UCTE5HVRB> since you'll likely want to know about creating/uploading content from source code....I'll anticipate the question and point you to <https://github.com/digitalrebar/colordemo>

attachments.title: digitalrebar/colordemo
attachments.text: Training Content. Contribute to digitalrebar/colordemo development by creating an account on GitHub.
